item.description: Ismail Haniyeh was Hamas’s chief negotiator in the cease-fire talks. Funerals for Haniyeh and Hezbollah’s Fuad Shukr, who was killed in Lebanon, will be held Thursday.

item.title: United and Delta cancel flights to Israel amid escalating conflict
item.dc:creator: Anika Seth, Frances Vinall
item.description: Some flights to Tel Aviv were suspended in the aftermath of the killing of a Hamas leader. Other cancellations have hit the region as governments warn against travel.

item.title: Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh assassinated; Netanyahu says Israel dealt ‘crushing blows’ to Iran-backed groups
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong, Susannah George, Rachel Pannett, Niha Masih, Victoria Bisset
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh led Hamas, the Palestinian group that runs Gaza, for over a decade. Hamas said he was killed in Tehran after attending the inauguration of Iran’s president.

item.title: Scotland Yard considering request to examine alleged phone-hacking coverup
item.dc:creator: Karla Adam, Sarah Ellison
item.description: A former U.K. prime minister called for police to examine allegations that William Lewis and others Scotland Yard considering request to examine alleged phone-hacking coverup. Lewis denies wrongdoing.

item.title: How false claims about a mass stabbing led to a riot in the U.K.
item.dc:creator: William Booth, Leo Sands
item.description: The riot in Southport, England, followed false claims that an immigrant was responsible for the attack on a Taylor Swift-themed dance class that killed three girls.

item.title: Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh killed in Iran, sparking fears of wider war
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix, Missy Ryan, Michael Birnbaum
item.description: The killing, which Iran and Hamas blamed on Israel and pledged to avenge, threatens to plunge the region further into chaos and raised fresh doubts about Gaza cease-fire talks.

item.title: Landslides, heavy rains kill at least 116 in south India’s Kerala state
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit, Anant Gupta
item.description: Downpours caused landslides in the hilly Wayanad district of southern India. Authorities fear the death toll will rise as bad weather complicates search-and-rescue efforts.

item.title: Third child dies after stabbing at Taylor Swift-themed dance class
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: The American singer wrote on Instagram that she was “completely in shock” after the mass stabbing attack in England.

item.title: U.S. military launches first airstrike in Iraq in months
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: The operation south of Baghdad targeted unspecified “combatants” and followed attacks on U.S. forces in recent days, officials said.

item.title: Son of ‘El Chapo’ pleads not guilty in federal court following dramatic arrest
item.dc:creator: Kim Bellware, Mary Beth Sheridan
item.description: In Mexico, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador demanded that Washington “tell the truth” about what happened in the arrests of two cartel leaders.

item.title: Belarus pardons German in terrorism case; Russia moves political prisoners
item.dc:creator: Mary Ilyushina
item.description: The unexpected pardon of Rico Krieger came as at least seven prisoners charged in political cases in Russia were moved from the penal colonies where they were being held to undisclosed locations over the past two days, lawyers and family members said.

item.title: Have babies for Russia: Putin presses women to embrace patriotism over feminism
item.dc:creator: Robyn Dixon, Francesca Ebel, Natalia Abbakumova
item.description: Women in Russia are being told to forgo education and careers to prioritize having many children, even as Putin’s war in Ukraine drains men from the workforce.

item.title: Blinken, Austin detail new U.S. security commitments for Philippines
item.dc:creator: Michael Birnbaum
item.description: The defense cooperation plans come as Manila seeks to bolster its ability to resist pressure from an increasingly assertive Chinese military in the South China Sea.

item.title: The Paris Olympics touted climate-friendly food. Athletes demanded more meat.
item.dc:creator: Rick Noack
item.description: What does a city proud of its culinary reputation, but also focused on the Olympics’ carbon footprint, serve to thousands of athletes seeking peak performance?

item.title: Images of a starving Palestinian boy went viral. The attention saved him.
item.dc:creator: Ruby Mellen, Joe Snell
item.description: Six-year-old Fadi al-Zant, a starving Palestinian boy, was saved by a viral photo during the Gaza hunger crisis.
